In-Place Operations in R

Source: vignettes/basic_usage.Rmd
basic_usage.Rmd
library(inplaceops)  # Replace with your actual package name

Introduction

This vignette demonstrates the use of in-place operations provided by the inplaceOps package. These operations allow you to modify variables directly, making your code more concise and potentially more efficient.

Arithmetic Operations

Addition 

x <- 5
x %+=% 3
print(x)
#> [1] 8

Subtraction 

y <- 10
y %-=% 4
print(y)
#> [1] 6

Vector Operations

Concatenation 

v <- c(1, 2, 3)
v %c=% c(4, 5)
print(v)
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5

Union 

set1 <- c(1, 2, 3)
set1 %union=% c(3, 4, 5)
print(set1)
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5

Set Difference 

set2 <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
set2 %setdiff=% c(2, 4)
print(set2)
#> [1] 1 3 5

Operations by Variable Name

These functions allow you to modify variables by their name as a string.

Addition 

z <- 7
assignPlus("z", 5)
print(z)
#> [1] 12

Concatenation 

words <- c("hello", "world")
assignC("words", "!")
print(words)
#> [1] "hello" "world" "!"

Set Difference 

numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
assignSetdiff("numbers", c(2, 4))
print(numbers)
#> [1] 1 3 5

Conclusion

These in-place operations can make your R code more readable and potentially more efficient, especially when working with large datasets or in loops where youâ€™re repeatedly modifying the same variable.
